* Local Tasks
** TODO Nonparametric Joint Scattering Estimation
 Location: [[file:~/Documents/Research/wavevib/NLIMPACTCL/e6_scatterel.m::%% Estimations of joint scattering]]
 [[edraw:]]
 + Scattering across the joint is taken to be governed by
   \begin{equation}
     \begin{bmatrix} a^-\\ b^+\end{bmatrix} =
     \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{r} & \mathbf{t}\\
       \mathbf{t} & \mathbf{r} \end{bmatrix}
     \begin{bmatrix} a^+\\ b^-\end{bmatrix}.
     \label{eq:scat1}
   \end{equation}
 + This relates the incoming wave coefficients (left-incoming, $a^+$ and right-incoming, $b^-$) to the outgoing wave coefficients (left-outgoing, $a^-$ and right-outgoing, $b^+$)
 + Since the scattering matrix exhibits directional equivalence, this can be rewritten as
   \begin{equation}
     \begin{bmatrix} a^- & b^+ \end{bmatrix} =
     \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{r} & \mathbf{t} \end{bmatrix}
     \begin{bmatrix} a^+ & b^-\\ b^- & a^+ \end{bmatrix}
     \label{eq:scat2}
   \end{equation}
 + In a practical setting, when all the wave-coefficients $a^{\pm}$ & $b^{\pm}$ are known/measured, [[cref:eq:scat2]] can be solved to yield,
   \begin{equation}
     \begin{bmatrix} \mathbf{r}\\ \mathbf{t} \end{bmatrix} =
     \frac{1}{{b^-}^2-{a^+}^2} \begin{bmatrix} b^-\cdot b^+ - a^-\cdot a^+\\
       a^-\cdot b^- - a^+\cdot b^+ \end{bmatrix}
     \label{eq:linscat}
   \end{equation}
 + The Euler-Bernoulli beam has harmonic as well as evanescent wave components. We denote these using the subscripts $(\cdot)_h$ & $(\cdot)_e$ respectively. The scattering relationship is,
   \begin{equation}
     \left[
       \begin{array}{c}
         a_h^-\\ a_e^-\\ \midrule b_h^+\\ b_e^+
       \end{array}\right] = \left[
       \begin{array}{cc|cc}
         r_{hh} & r_{he} & t_{hh} & t_{he}\\
         r_{eh} & r_{ee} & t_{eh} & t_{ee}\\
         \midrule
         t_{hh} & t_{he} & r_{hh} & r_{he}\\
         t_{eh} & t_{ee} & r_{eh} & r_{ee}
       \end{array}
     \right] \left[
       \begin{array}{c}
         a_h^+\\ a_e^+\\ \midrule b_h^-\\ b_e^-
       \end{array}\right]
   \end{equation}
 + There are eight unknown scattering coefficients ($r/t_{h/e,h/e}$) but only four equations in the above.
